facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 87 of 1957 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 1, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE- JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 87 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 1, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated November 30, 1954, of the said Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 355 of 1952.

facts.text: Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955 arose out of the judgment and order dated November 30, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 355 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 1, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated November 30, 1954, of the said Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 355 of 1952.

facts.text: The respondent is a firm registered under the Indian Partnership Act dealing in Bullion, Gold and Silver ornaments and forward contracts in Silver Bullion at Banaras in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-The facts leading up to this appeal lie within a narrow companypass. The respondent is a firm registered under the Indian Partnership Act dealing in Bullion, Gold and Silver ornaments and forward companytracts in Silver Bullion at Banaras in the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer, Banaras (appellant No. 1) assessed the respondent to U.P. Sales Tax on its forward transactions in Silver Bullion for assessment years 1948-49, 1949-50 and 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1948-49, 1949-50 and 1950-51 the Sales Tax Officer, Banaras, the appellant No. 1 herein assessed the respondent to U. P. Sales Tax on its forward transactions in Silver Bullion.

facts.text: The respondent deposited Rs. 150-12-0, Rs. 470-0-0 and Rs. 741-0-0 for the three years which were appropriated towards sales tax liability on May 31, 1949, October 30, 1950 and August 22, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had deposited the sums of Rs. 150- 12-0, Rs. 470-0-0 and Rs. 741-0-0 for the said 1352 three years which sums were appropriated to-wards the payment of the sales tax liability of the firm under the respective assessment orders passed on May 31, 1949, October 30, 1950 and August 22, 1951.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held levy of sales tax on forward transactions ultra vires on February 27, 1952 in Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash v. Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: The levy of sales tax on forward transactions was held to be ultra vires, by the High Court of Allahabad by its judgment delivered on February 27, 1952, in Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash v. Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur  1  and the respondent by its letter dated July 8, 1952, asked for a refund of the amounts of sales tax paid as aforesaid.

facts.text: Respondent asked for refund of sales tax amounts by letter dated July 8, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondent by its letter dated July 8, 1952, asked for a refund of the amounts of sales tax paid as aforesaid.

facts.text: Commissioner of Sales Tax, U.P. (appellant No. 2) refused refund by letter dated July 19, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant No. 2, the Commissioner of Sales Tax, U. P., Lucknow, however, by his letter dated July 19, 1952, refused to refund the same.

facts.text: Respondent filed Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 355 of 1952 under Art. 226 in Allahabad High Court seeking certiorari to quash assessment orders and mandamus for refund of Rs. 1,365-12-0.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereafter filed in the High Court of Allahabad the Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 355 of 1952 under Art. 226 of the Constitution and asked for a writ of certiorari for quashing the aforesaid three assessment orders and a writ of mandamus requiring the appellants to refund the aforesaid amounts aggregating to Rs. 1,365-12-0.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirmed Allahabad High Court judgment on May 3, 1954 in Sales Tax Officer, Pilibhit v. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Allahabad High Court was companyfirmed by this Court on May 3, 1954, in Sales Tax Officer, Pilibhit v. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash    and the writ petition aforesaid was heard by Chaturvedi J.

facts.text: Chaturvedi J. quashed the assessment orders regarding forward contracts in silver and issued writ of mandamus for refund on November 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judge by an order dated November 30, 1954, quashed the said assessment orders in so far as they purported to assess the respondent in respect of forward companytracts in silver and also issued a writ of mandamus directing the appellants to refund the amounts paid by the respondent.

facts.text: Appellants filed Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955 against the order of Chaturvedi J.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955 in the High Court of Allahabad against that order of the learned Judge.

facts.text: Division Bench of Allahabad High Court dismissed the Special Appeal on December 1, 1955 with costs, holding s.72 Indian Contract Act applies.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the said High Court heard the said appeal on December 1, 1955. ... It accordingly dismissed the appeal with companyts.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(b) on July 30, 1956 on undertaking by Advocate-General.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for a certificate under Art. 133 1  b  of the Constitution which certificate was granted by the High Court on July 30, 1956, on the Advocate- Generals giving to the Court an undertaking that the State will, in any event, pay the companyts, charges and expenses incurred by or on behalf of the respondent as taxed by this Court.

facts.text: Appellants are Sales Tax Officer Banaras (No.1), Commissioner Sales Tax U.P. (No.2), State of U.P. (No.3).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has accordingly companye up for hearing and final disposal before us at the instance of the Sales Tax Officer, Banaras, appellant No. 1, the Commissioner, Sales Tax, U.P., Lucknow, appellant No. 2 and the State of U.P., appellant No. 3.

anchor.surface_text: under the respective assessment orders passed on May 31, 1949, October 30, 1950 and August 22, 1951.

facts.text: Total refund amount aggregating to Rs. 1,365-12-0.

anchor.surface_text: requiring the appellants to refund the aforesaid amounts aggregating to Rs. 1,365-12-0.

facts.text: Advocate-General argued before High Court that amounts paid under mistake of law irrecoverable.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by the Advocate-General on, behalf of the appellants that the amounts in dispute were paid by the respondent under a mistake of law and were therefore irrecoverable.

facts.text: Advocate-General stated respondent ought not to proceed by Art. 226 petition.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by BHAGWATI J. on September 23, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: N. Sanyal, Additional Solicitor-General of India, Gopalakrishnan and T. M. Sen, for the Union of India  Intervener . 1958. September 23.

facts.text: High Court concluded s.72 applies and State must refund moneys unlawfully received.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the companyclusion that s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act applied to the present case and the State Government must refund the moneys unlawfully received by it from the respondent on account of Sales Tax.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a firm registered under the Indian Partnership Act dealing in Bullion, Gold and Silver ornaments and forward companytracts in Silver Bullion

issues.text: whether s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act applies to the facts of the present case

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act applies to the facts of the present case. The learned Additional Solicitor-General appearing for the appellants tried to urge before us that the procedure laid down in the U.P. Sales Tax Act by way of appeal and or revision against the assessment orders in question ought to have been followed by the respondent and that not having been done the respondent was debarred from proceeding in the civil courts for obtaining a refund of the monies paid as aforesaid.

issues.text: whether the procedure laid down in the U.P. Sales Tax Act by way of appeal and revision ought to have been followed by the respondent instead of writ petition under Art. 226

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor-General appearing for the appellants tried to urge before us that the procedure laid down in the U.P. Sales Tax Act by way of appeal and or revision against the assessment orders in question ought to have been followed by the respondent and that not having been done the respondent was debarred from proceeding in the civil courts for obtaining a refund of the monies paid as aforesaid.

issues.text: whether payments in discharge of tax liability under U.P. Sales Tax Act made voluntarily without protest disentitle recovery under s.72

anchor.surface_text: It was thus urged that having regard to the circumstances of the present case, i in so far as the payments were in discharge of the liability under the U.P. Sales Tax Act and were voluntary payments without protest and also ii inasmuch as the monies which had been received by the State of U. P. had not been retained but had been spent away by it, the respondent was disentitled to recover the said amounts.

issues.text: whether the respondent was disentitled to recover because the monies received had not been retained but spent away by the State

anchor.surface_text: It was thus urged that having regard to the circumstances of the present case, i in so far as the payments were in discharge of the liability under the U.P. Sales Tax Act and were voluntary payments without protest and also ii inasmuch as the monies which had been received by the State of U. P. had not been retained but had been spent away by it, the respondent was disentitled to recover the said amounts.

anchor.surface_text: There may in a particular case be circumstances which disentitle a plaintiff by estoppel or otherwise. We are of opinion that this interpretation put by their Lordships of the Privy Council on s. 72 is correct.

arguments.claim: s.72 applies to facts; no distinction between mistake of law and fact; plain terms include both

anchor.surface_text: As will be observed the section in terms does not make any distinction between a mistake of law or a mistake of fact. The term mistake has been used without any qualification or limitation whatever and comprises within its scope a mistake of law as well as a mistake of fact.

arguments.claim: Foreign law analogies not applicable; interpret plain terms of s.72 without reference to English etc. law

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to observe at the outset that what we have got to consider are the plain terms of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act as enacted by the Legislature. If the terms are plain and unambiguous we cannot have resort to the position in law as it obtained in England or in other countries

arguments.claim: Privy Council in Shiba Prasad correctly interprets s.72 to include mistake of law

anchor.surface_text: No question of estoppel can ever arise where both the parties, as in the present case, are labouring under the mistake of law and one party is not more to blame than the other.

holdings.text: Both those contentions were, however, not available to him by reason of the categorical statement made by the Advocate-General before the High Court. The whole matter had proceeded on the basis that the respondent was entitled to recover the amount claimed in the writ petition which was filed. No such point had been taken either in the grounds of appeal or in the statement of case filed before us in this Court and we did not feel justified in allowing the learned Additional Solicitor-General to take this point at this stage.

anchor.surface_text: Both those contentions were, however, not available to him by reason of the categorical statement made by the Advocate-General before the High Court. The whole matter had proceeded on the basis that the respondent was entitled to recover the amount claimed in the writ petition which was filed. No such point had been taken either in the grounds of appeal or in the statement of case filed before us in this Court and we did not feel justified in allowing the learned Additional Solicitor-General to take this point at this stage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Categorical concession by Advocate-General in High Court appeal binds appellants; point not raised in grounds of appeal or statement of case.

holdings.text: As will be observed the section in terms does not make any distinction between a mistake of law or a mistake of fact. The term mistake has been used without any qualification or limitation whatever and comprises within its scope a mistake of law as well as a mistake of fact.

anchor.surface_text: As will be observed the section in terms does not make any distinction between a mistake of law or a mistake of fact. The term mistake has been used without any qualification or limitation whatever and comprises within its scope a mistake of law as well as a mistake of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain and unambiguous textual interpretation of s.72; no qualification limits 'mistake' to fact only.

holdings.text: We are of opinion that this interpretation put by their Lordships of the Privy Council on s. 72 is correct. There is no warrant for ascribing any limited meaning to the word mistake as has been used therein and it is wide enough to cover not only a mistake of fact but also a mistake of law.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this interpretation put by their Lordships of the Privy Council on s. 72 is correct. There is no warrant for ascribing any limited meaning to the word mistake as has been used therein and it is wide enough to cover not only a mistake of fact but also a mistake of law. There is no conflict between the provisions of s. 72 on the one hand and ss. 21 and 22 of the Indian Contract Act on the other

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorsement of Privy Council ratio in Shiba Prasad Singh v. Srish Chandra Nandi; rejects limited interpretation influenced by English law or ss.21/22.

holdings.text: Voluntary payment of such tax liability was not by itself enough to preclude the respondent from recovering the said amounts, once it was established that the payments were made under a mistake of law. On a true interpretation of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act the only two circumstances there indicated as entitling the party to recover the money back are that the monies must have been paid by mistake or under coercion.

anchor.surface_text: It was thus urged that having regard to the circumstances of the present case, i in so far as the payments were in discharge of the liability under the U.P. Sales Tax Act and were voluntary payments without protest and also ii inasmuch as the monies which had been received by the State of U. P. had not been retained but had been spent away by it, the respondent was disentitled to recover the said amounts. Here also, we may observe that these contentions were not specifically urged in the High Court or in the statement of case filed by the appellants in this court but we heard arguments on the same, as they were necessarily involved in the question whether s. 72 of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Voluntariness relevant only to coercion limb of s.72; mistake limb applies irrespective if established.

holdings.text: No question of estoppel can ever arise where both the parties, as in the present case, are labouring under the mistake of law and one party is not more to blame than the other.

anchor.surface_text: the principle of estoppel which has been adverted to by the Privy Council in Shiba Prasad Singh v. Srish Chandra Nandi as disentitling the plaintiff to recover the monies paid under mistake can best be illustrated by the decision of the Appeal Court in England reported in Holt v. Markham - here it was held that as the defendant had been led by the plaintiffs conduct to believe that he might treat the money as his own, and in that belief had altered his position by spending it, the plaintiffs were estopped from alleging that it was paid under a mistake and this brings us to a consideration of point No. 2 above stated. Re ii Whether the principle of estoppel applies or there are circumstances attendant upon the transaction which disentitle the respondent to recover back the monies, depends upon the facts and circumstances of each case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estoppel requires representation acted upon to detriment; no estoppel in mutual mistake of law.

holdings.text: Merely because the State of U. P. had not retained the monies paid by the respondent but had spent them away in the ordinary course of the business of the State would not make any difference to the position and under the plain terms of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act the respondent would be entitled to recover back the monies paid by it to the State of U.P. under mistake of law.

anchor.surface_text: Merely because the State of U. P. had not retained the monies paid by the respondent but had spent them away in the ordinary course of the business of the State would not make any difference to the position and under the plain terms of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act the respondent would be entitled to recover back the monies paid by it to the State of U.P. under mistake of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear terms of s.72 prevail over equitable considerations like expenditure of funds; no change in position disentitling recovery without estoppel.

anchor.surface_text: Merely because the State of U. P. had number retained the monies paid by the respondent but had spent them away in the ordinary companyrse of the business of the State would number make any difference to the position and under the plain terms of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act the respondent would be entitled to recover back the monies paid by it to the State of U.P. under mistake of law.

anchor.surface_text: Both those contentions were, however, not available to him by reason of the categorical statement made by the Advocate-General before the High Court. The whole matter had proceeded on the basis that the respondent was entitled to recover the amount claimed in the writ petition which was filed. No such point had been taken either in the grounds of appeal or in the statement of case filed before us in this Court and we did not feel justified in allowing the learned Additional Solicitor-General to take this point at this stage.

anchor.surface_text: As will be observed the section in terms does not make any distinction between a mistake of law or a mistake of fact. The term mistake has been used without any qualification or limitation whatever and comprises within its scope a mistake of law as well as a mistake of fact.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this interpretation put by their Lordships of the Privy Council on s. 72 is correct. There is no warrant for ascribing any limited meaning to the word mistake as has been used therein and it is wide enough to cover not only a mistake of fact but also a mistake of law. There is no conflict between the provisions of s. 72 on the one hand and ss. 21 and 22 of the Indian Contract Act on the other

P. had not been retained but had been spent away by it, the respondent was disentitled to recover the said amounts. anchor.surface_text: the principle of estoppel which has been adverted to by the Privy Council in Shiba Prasad Singh v. Srish Chandra Nandi as disentitling the plaintiff to recover the monies paid under mistake can best be illustrated by the decision of the Appeal Court in England reported in Holt v. Markham - here it was held that as the defendant had been led by the plaintiffs conduct to believe that he might treat the money as his own, and in that belief had altered his position by spending it, the plaintiffs were estopped from alleging that it was paid under a mistake and this brings us to a consideration of point No. 2 above stated. Re ii Whether the principle of estoppel applies or there are circumstances attendant upon the transaction which disentitle the respondent to recover back the monies, depends upon the facts and circumstances of each case.
